body.p: Look at the two feedback loops, above, regulating blood glucose associated with the pancreas. Which type of homeostasis feedback is involved in these two examples?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The initiation event and result would have to be the same because this would cause more of the same stimulus.
Correct. The result is opposite, which stops the initial stimulus and release of the hormone.

question.body: Which cells of the pancreas are involved in this plasma glucose homeostasis?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Acini cells are the exocrine cells producing enzymes and bicarbonate ions.
Correct. Alpha produces glucagon and beta produces insulin.
Incorrect. Delta cells secrete the paracrine somatostatin.
Incorrect. F or PP cells secrete the paracrine pancreatic polypeptide.

part.hint: These are NOT the exocrine cells around the ducts.

question.body: Most body cells have receptors for insulin; they have even recently been discovered on brain cells. But glucagon target cells are more specific, being involved in the metabolic processes that produce glucose for release back into the blood. Which of the following would you predict would be effector cells for glucagon?

multiple_choice.choice: skeletal muscle fibers and epithelial cells

response.feedback: Incorrect. Erythrocytes without a nucleus and limited metabolism would not be involved in this metabolic response to increase blood glucose even though found in blood.
Incorrect. Neurons depend upon constant supply of glucose and would not be involved in the release to blood.
Incorrect. These would take up glucose and muscle even stores glycogen, but would not be involved in the release to blood.
Correct. The main target is liver, but even adipose cells can indirectly be involved in glucose conservation by providing alternative fuel to body cells.

part.hint: These cells would have to accomplish the effects depicted in the feedback loop.
